The process

A rant

Three attempts

  1. Managing focus directly
  2. Using aria-activedescendant

Spoilers

Research

  • Surprisingly few resources on basic selects
  • All focused on building more complex components like autocompletes

Native behaviour

The bare minimum should be to reproduce native browser behaviour

  • A button that triggers a popup menu
  • Usable without a mouse
  • Accessible to assistive technologies

ARIA roles

aria-role lets divs roleplay as something more interesting

Listbox

The listbox role is used to identify an element that creates
a list from which a user may select one or more items

‚ÄîMDN

Related to ‚Äúcombobox‚Äù (usually used for autocompletes)

Minimal markup

<button
  aria-label="Destination select menu"
  aria-expanded="false"
  aria-haspopup="true">
  {selectedOption}
</button>
<ul
  role="listbox"
  tabindex="-1">
  <li
    id="option-0"
    role="option"
    value="tattooine">
    Tattooine
  </li>
</ul>

First attempt

Problems

  • Managing focus is annoying, especially in React.
  • Async state changes meant focus got out of sync
  • We didn‚Äôt want to rely on refs

Second attempt

aria-activedescendant to the rescue!

The aria-activedescendant property provides an alternative method of managing focus for interactive elements

‚ÄîW3C

Minimal markup

...
<ul
  role="listbox"
  tabindex="-1"
  aria-activedescendant="option-{activeIndex}">
  ...
</ul>

Magic ARIA property

Just update aria-activedescendant on the parent with the ID of the currently active child‚Äîsimple right?

Problems

  • The implementation is still kind of buggy
  • Chromium has an open bug for this
  • Safari has a similar one for role="combobox"

Third and final attempt

  • How do third party libraries solve this?
  • Downshift is amazing
  • Live regions!

Live regions

Screenreaders read out whatever text you dump in them. Allows us create a custom ‚Äòaural UI‚Äô

  • aria-live="assertive"
  • role="status"

Minimal markup

...
<ul
  role="listbox"
  tabindex="-1">
  ...
</ul>
<div
  class="visually-hidden"
  aria-live="assertive"
  role="status">
  {a11y message}
</div>

Voiceover demo

Problems

  • Changes the default screenreader experience
  • You‚Äôre now responsible for everything
  • Translations!

What did we gain?

We spent a week researching and building‚Äîended up with ~240 lines of code to maintain and a functionally worse component.

Not a great trade-off.

The real solution

Just use a native <select>.

You can style the button to look right, then let users have a platform-specific experience for the actual menu.

Takeaway

I don‚Äôt want to discourage anyone from building cool stuff.

80% accessible is better than 0%.

But maybe don‚Äôt spend a week needlessly replicating browser functionality üòâ
